ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle:
Structural and optical properties of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O multiple quantum wells grown on
r
$r$ -plane sapphire substrates by plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials, Cyrus Tang Center for Sensor Materials and Applications, Department of Materials Science and Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
This work investigates the structural and optical properties of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O multiple quantum wells (MQWs), which have been prepared on
r
$r$ -plane sapphire substrates by plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy (MBE). The MQWs are (
11
2 ¯
0
$11\bar{2}0$ ) oriented (
a
$a$ -plane) as identified by the X-ray diffraction pattern. Structural properties are anisotropic and surfaces of MQWs show stripes running along the ZnO
c
$c$ -axis direction. Sharp interfaces between the well layers and barrier layers can be clearly resolved by the secondary ion mass spectroscopy (SIMS) analysis. The room-temperature photoluminescence (PL) resulting from the well regions exhibits a significant blueshift with respect to ZnO single layer. Exciton emission in the ZnO QW is resolved into two components in the temperature dependence of the PL spectra. Two types of excitons are responsible for this feature. The excitons trapped by the potential minima dominate at low temperature, and the excitons localized in the “free exciton states” dominate at relatively high temperature. An activation energy of 7.3 meV for quenching of the exciton emission is in good agreement with the transition of the two types of excitons.

ArticleNote.Heading: Electronic Supplementary Material

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
ZnO and its related alloys have drawn a great deal of attention for their promising applications in optoelectric devices, owing to its wide bad gap of 3.37 eV and large exciton binding energy of 60 meV at room temperature [1, 2]. In order to design high performance optoelectronic devices, the ZnO-based multiple quantum wells (MQWs) structures play an important role. Since ZnMgO is considered as a suitable alloy to create a barrier layer for ZnO quantum wells (QWs) [3–5], much effort has been devoted towards the fabrication and characterization of ZnO/ZnMgO MQWs by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) [6, 7], molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) [8, 9], and metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) [10]. However, a majority of researches concentrate on polar ZnO/ZnMgO MQWs, which are grown along the
c
$c$ -axis direction. Unfortunately, the exhibition of the quantum confined Stark effect (QCSE) due to the large internal electric fields along
c
$c$ -axis direction in polar ZnO/ZnMgO MQWs will make negative effects on the device properties, such as a decrease of internal quantum efficiency of the emitting devices resulting from a decrease in the overlapping of the electron and hole wave functions in the QW [11–13]. In order to eliminate the polarization effects, the growth of non-polar ZnO-based quantum structures with the polar
c
$c$ -direction of ZnO lying in the growth plane is therefore highly desirable. Recently, non-polar ZnO/ZnMgO MQWs have been realized on various substrates, such as
r
$r$ -plane sapphire substrate [14–16],
a
$a$ -plane ZnO substrate [17, 18], and
m
$m$ -plane ZnO substrate [19, 20]. Nevertheless, the research on non-polar ZnO/ZnMgO MQWs is far less than the research on polar ones. Moreover, there have been few reports on the optical properties of non-polar ZnO/ZnMgO MQWs in spite of their special intrinsic characteristics relative to
c
$c$ -plane MQWs [15].

In the present work, we report on the structural and photoluminescence (PL) properties of 5-period non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs grown on
r
$r$ -plane sapphire by plasma-assisted MBE. The properties of exciton luminescence in the MQWs are investigated by temperature-dependent PL spectra. Furthermore, a mechanism is put forward and proved by the deduction of activation energy.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
Non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs were grown on
2 ″
$2''$
r
$r$ -plane sapphire substrates by plasma-assisted MBE technique. Elemental zinc (6N grade), magnesium (6N grade), and oxygen radio frequency (RF) plasma (O2 gas of 6N grade) were used as the sources.
r
$r$ -plane sapphire substrate was cleaned ultrasonically with acetone, ethanol, and deionized water for 5 min at room temperature, respectively. Prior to deposition, the substrate was thermally cleaned by heating at 300 °C in the preparation chamber for several hours, then transferred into the growth chamber and treated in oxygen plasma exposure at 250 °C for 20 min followed by further cleaning at 800 °C for 30 min under ultrahigh vacuum achieved by a liquid nitrogen supply. After these cleaning processes, a 100 nm thick ZnO buffer layer was grown at 300 °C and annealed at 600 °C for 5 min for better film crystallinity and smoother surface. A 120 nm thick Zn0.81Mg0.19O layer was subsequently grown on the buffer layer at 650 °C, and then 5-period ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs were deposited on the Zn0.81Mg0.19O layer. The thicknesses of ZnO well layer and Zn0.81Mg0.19O barrier layer are 3 nm and 8 nm, respectively, which are controlled by varying the deposition time. A schematic diagram of the structure is shown in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1
A schematic of 5-period non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs structures

In order to determine the Mg content in Zn
1 − x
$_{1-x}$ Mg x O barrier layer, a single-layer Zn
1 − x
$_{1-x}$ Mg x O film was grown under the same conditions by plasma-assisted MBE. The Mg content was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which showed a Mg content of 18.6 at.% in the film. Henceforth, the MQWs are referred as ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs.

The morphology of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs was characterized by atomic force microscopy (AFM). The crystalline structure was analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a Cu
K α
$K_{\alpha}$ radiation source (
λ = 1.54056
Å
). The Mg depth profile of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs was investigated by secondary ion mass spectroscopy (SIMS) measurements. The optical properties were characterized by PL spectra on a FLS 920 fluorescence spectrometer (Edinburgh Instruments) using a He–Cd laser (
λ = 325
nm
$\lambda=325~\mathrm{nm}$ ) as the excitation source.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 2(a) shows a XRD pattern of ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs grown on
r
$r$ -plane sapphire in
θ – 2 θ
$\theta\mbox{--}2\theta$ configuration. In addition to the sapphire (
01
1 ¯
2
$01\bar{1}2$ ) and (
02
2 ¯
4
$02\bar{2}4$ ) peaks, only ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O (
11
2 ¯
0
$11\bar{2}0$ ) peak appears in XRD pattern, suggesting that ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs grown on
r
$r$ -plane sapphire have pure
a
$a$ -plane orientation. Figure 2(b) shows the AFM image of the MQWs in
5 × 5
μm 2
range. The surface morphology exhibits the features commonly observed in non-polar layers with stripes elongated along the
c
$c$ -axis lying in the growth plane. In addition, the root mean square (rms) surface roughness of the non-polar MQWs is about 1.33 nm. The smooth surfaces ensure good interfaces of the non-polar MQWs. The XRD and AFM studies imply that the ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs exhibit non-polar
a
$a$ -plane single crystal orientation, which is proposed to avoid built-in electric fields along the
c
$c$ -axis.
Fig. 2
(a) XRD spectrum of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs in
θ – 2 θ
$\theta\mbox{--}2\theta$ geometry. (b) AFM image of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs from a scale
5 × 5
μm 2

In order to investigate Mg composition distribution in the non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs, a depth profile was carried out by SIMS measurements, as shown in Fig. 3. Gaussian line shapes were used to fit the peaks. Five sharp peaks can be clearly resolved with the etch time increasing, suggesting the sharp interfaces between the well layers and barrier layers, which is in good agreement with the structure schematic of the non-polar MQWs. Slight interdiffusion of Mg can be observed in the non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs due to high temperature growth.
Fig. 3
SIMS depth profile of Mg in the non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs

Figure 4 shows the 14 K PL spectrum of the non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs. It shows three clear peaks located at 3.59 eV, 3.42 eV and 3.38 eV, respectively. The weak emission at 3.59 eV comes from the Zn0.81Mg0.19O capper/barrier layers. This certificates the efficient barrier-to-well injection of carriers. The strong emission at 3.42 eV can be attributed to excitons in the ZnO well, which shows a blueshift compared with ZnO epitaxial film. This blueshift behavior is naturally attributed to the expected quantum confinement effect. The peak at 3.38 eV is a typical near-band-edge (NBE) emission from the ZnO buffer layer. Furthermore, on the low-energy side, two shoulders with about 72 meV separated are attributed to the first-order and second-order longitudinal optical (LO) phonon replicas of the NBE emission from the ZnO buffer layer. The inset of Fig. 4 shows the room-temperature PL spectrum of the MQWs. A strong NBE emission at around 3.38 eV is observed. The blueshift of 60 meV compared with the free exciton energy of epitaxial ZnO film (3.32 eV) [21] is believed to be the results of room-temperature quantum confinement effect, which indicates a good interface and crystal quality of the MQWs.
Fig. 4
The 14 K PL spectrum of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs. Inset shows the room-temperature PL spectrum of the MQWs

Figure 5 shows the temperature dependence of PL spectra of the non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs. It can be seen that both the position and the line shape of exciton emission in the ZnO QW are sensitive to temperature, and clearly there are two components (denoted as the LX1 peak and LX2 peak) contributing to the PL. As the temperature increases, both LX1 and LX2 peaks redshift gradually due to the band gap shrinkage. Within the temperature range 14–90 K, the LX1 peak is dominated in the PL spectra. Within the temperature range 90–220 K, the LX2 peak has almost the same height as the LX1 peak. At further higher temperature, the LX2 peak is dominated in the spectra and two peaks are gradually unresolved. A similar phenomenon has been reported [22, 23] in polar ZnO-based MQWs. Furthermore, the emission from the Zn0.81Mg
O
0.19
$_{0.19}\mathrm{O}$ capper/barrier layer and emission from the ZnO buffer layer decay quickly with increasing temperature.
Fig. 5
Temperature-dependent PL spectra of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs within the temperature range 14–300 K

To better understand the localization, relaxation, and recombination mechanisms of excitons in the non-polar MQWs, a schematic of the band diagram and the exciton behavior of the non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg
O
0.19
$_{0.19}\mathrm{O}$ MQWs are shown in Fig. 6. In MQWs, the interface fluctuations (well width fluctuation, microscopic composition fluctuation in the barrier layers, etc.) could result in a depth fluctuation of the potential well [22, 24, 25]. In other words, a “potential valley”, which is usually called potential minimum, exists in the potential well. Photoexcited free excitons localized in the potential well are easily trapped by these potential minima at low temperature. Thus, only the LX1 peak is observed within the temperature range 14–90 K. As the temperature increases, some thermalized excitons have sufficient thermal energy to detrap out of the potential minima into “free exciton states” within their lifetime, while these “free excitons” are still localized in the whole well plane. And other excitons remain localized in the potential minima. So both LX1 and LX2 peaks are observed within the temperature range 90–220 K. At further high temperature, most excitons localized in the potential minima transit to “free exciton states”, which results in only observation of the higher energy LX2 peak. In order to further prove the mechanism mentioned above, we also deduce the activation energy for quenching of the exciton emission. Figure 7 shows the integrated intensities of the exciton emission as functions of reciprocal temperature. In steady state, integrated intensities can be described by the equation [26]
1

)
,
$$ I = I_{0}/ \bigl( 1 + a_{1}e^{ - E_{a_{_{1}}}/kT} + a_{2}e^{ - E_{a_{2}}/kT} \bigr), $$ where
E a
$E_{a}$ denotes the activation energy for the thermal quenching process. Fitting Eq. (1) to the data gives rise to two activation energies of about 7.3 meV and 24.4 meV, indicating two competitive nonradiative recombination channels. And these results are very similar to the values reported by Chauveau et al. [17] and Li et al. [16] in non-polar ZnO/ZnMgO quantum well. It should be noted that a low
E a
$E_{a}$ value of 7.3 meV is of the order of the thermal energy of
k B
T
$k_{B}T$ (
T ≈ 85
K
$T \approx 85~\mathrm{K}$ ), suggesting that thermionic emission of excitons out of the potential minima, which is in good agreement with that observed in the temperature dependence of PL spectra. Moreover, since the calculated activation energy of 24.4 meV is much lower than the barrier height, thermal quenching of the exciton emission is not due to the thermal escape of excitons from the ZnO wells into the Zn0.81Mg0.19O barriers. Instead, thermal quenching of the exciton emission may be attributed to nonradiative centers.
Fig. 6
A schematic of the band diagram and the exciton behavior of non-polar ZnO/Zn0.81Mg0.19O MQWs
Fig. 7
Integrated intensities of the exciton emission as a function of reciprocal temperature

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
In summary, non-polar
ZnO/Zn 0.81
Mg 0.19
O
$\mbox{ZnO/Zn}_{0.81}\mbox{Mg}_{0.19}\mbox{O}$ MQWs have been prepared on
r
$r$ -plane sapphire substrates by plasma-assisted MBE. Pure
a
$a$ -plane single crystal orientation, highly anisotropic morphology with stripes elongated along the
c
$c$ -axis direction, and a significant blueshift in the room-temperature PL spectrum have been achieved. Sharp interfaces also can be clearly resolved by SIMS analysis. The exciton emission in the ZnO QW is resolved into two components in temperature-dependent PL spectra. A mechanism of two types of excitons is used to explain this feature. One of the components is due to the excitons trapped by the potential minima, and the other one is due to the excitons localized in the “free exciton states” in the QW. The calculated activation energies further prove the mechanism.
